historyelements.title: How It Started
historyelements.history: Originally the National Society of Black Engineers was the Black Society of Engineers. The BSE was started by Edward Barnette and Fred Cooper in 1971. With the help of Edward A. Coleman, Anthony Harris, Brian Harris, Stanley L. Kirtley, John W. Logan Jr. and George A. Smith the National Society of Black Engineers was established in 1974.

historyelements.title: The Logo
historyelements.history: The symbol for NSBE represents the organizations various aspects. The torch stands for the everlasting desire to achieve and have a positive impact on society. The yellow lightning bolts represent the striking impact that members of the society will have on the industry.

historyelements.title: The Mission Statement
historyelements.history: The mission of the National Society of Black Engineers is to increase the number of culturally responsible Black Engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally and positively impact the community.

historyelements.title: NSBE Today
historyelements.history: Today NSBE is one of the largest student-governed organizations based in the United States. NSBE currently has over 300 pre-collegiate, collegiate, and professional chapters that consist of tens of thousands of members spread across 6 regions. The organization also plans on graduating 10,000 African American Engineers by the year 2025.

historyelements.title: The UNCC Chapter of NSBE
historyelements.history: The UNC Charlotte chapter offers leadership training, professional and academic development, mentorship opportunities, community service and outreach programs, and networking opportunities. The goal of the chapter is to create community within the College of Engineering and College of Computing and Informatics here at UNC Charlotte.
